comments.commentBody:
Yes, Maureen, The Merchant of Venice is a really good play. It is always wonderful when someone discovers the greatness of Shakespeare's plays for the first time.

There were Jews then as now, and Catholics too. There were women and sexual confusion and bisexuality and all manner of sins just as there are now.

Good old William--He could always be counted on to write a good play.

Is that all there is to the column? Where is the anti-Catholicism in today's piece?

Having been a vegetarian for as long as I can remember, the talk of eating an animal is always unpleasant, but whenever the talk is about exotic animals, endangered animals, the feeling I get is more of that of being completely sick to my stomach. The killing and eating of these animals is a materialistic thing, and something a lot of people don’t interpret to be a bad thing. The morale of societies is low and it will take more than a talking to in order to get the idea through their heads. Meals made of animals such as pangolin can cost several hundreds of dollars. An average person in China may not be able to afford such “luxuries,” and even though the capture and consumption of some of these animals may be illegal, it isn’t always the common folk who are feasting on these delicacies. The price to feed government officials in China for a year is more than 12.5 billion U.S. dollars, which is enough to build one million primary schools in China’s poor areas. It will certainly take a lot of time and effort before any change is seen in strange consumptions of the Chinese.

"Demolishing these houses and building modern appartments is an undisputable good thing for all the people who actually lives there, and people who lives on the otherside of planet who never lived one day in these places and never even visited or talked to the people who lives there should shut up and mind their own business." -- #14, JesterJames

------------------------

People used this same excuse to tear down black neighborhoods ("ghettos") throughout America in the 60's. They were then moved to "modern" complexes of high-rises on the outskirts of town (usually in a neighborhood far away from the mayor's neighborhood, if not in another town) that the residents had to rent -- not own. The people felt no sense of ownership or pride in their building and resentment, crime, and disrepair quickly turned these into ghettos -- again.

It's too bad China didn't learn from our mistakes.

Getting rid of the corruption, waste and bloat in existing programs, including military contracts, Homeland Security, expense accounts for in the three branches of the Federal Government and social programs would shrink the deficit 1,2,3.  But outright canceling such programs would be folly -- the old "throwing out the baby with the bath water" syndrome.  The real culprit is corruption, not defending our nation and helping our citizens.

"In a country with eight million long-term unemployed people..."

The May 2010 official UK long-term (12+ months) unemployed figure is just shy of 800,000 - still appallingly high. Perhaps you referred to the official calculation that 8.1 million persons of working age are economically "inactive"? According to the UK National Statistics office, those classified among the "inactive" include full-time students and the long-term sick.

Gulou is a really great place. The neighborhood is really charming, and its residents have been dreading this demolition for a long time.

I think that it's terrible that the government is going to tear down residences and break down the little history that's actually preserved in Beijing. Of course, the government has been doing this without care for a long time, but they do this without thinking of the consequences. Already, with changes such as simplified Chinese, mainland Chinese people lose bits and bits of China's history...

Very sad. Maybe the change will encourage more outsiders to invest in things in China, but unfortunately it won't benefit the Chinese that have lived in Gulou for generations.

What the city authorities are doing is tantamount to cultural genocide. I've watched other great old neighborhoods like Dongzhimennei and Qianmen disappear to developers' myopic greed in collusion with corrupt local district governments. History will condemn these thieves who are stealing not only China's ancient urban legacy, but one that belongs to the world. Pity UNESCO doesn't have access troops to protect the pieces of Peking that still remain.
When will our liberals learn the lesson the Lib-Dems have learned, that you can't borrow your way to financial recovery?  Keynes was a dangerous fool.  That goes double for his deluded followers.

Europe has preserved many of it's old city centers, and nobody would suggest bulldozing those now to improve the lives of residents. This little area is one of the best and last parts of Beijing to get in touch with the humble side of it's history. Anyone who has visited Beijing has seen how they love to display the grand side of their history. The humble side is an embarrassment, to be erased. It has no value to the rich leaders.

The hutong is largely an attraction for westerners in present form. Once made into an official historical theme park, it can attract domestic tourists the way the Olympic park does. The grand historical theme, the official message, can be custom tailored for their consumption. It's also a money game of course, one of the biggest tourist attractions is a neighborhood full of poor, old residents. Profit potential is therefore not realized. Those tourist dollars must be reaped and routed centrally instead.

The tax increases Cameron has proposed are adamently in favor of the wealthy in Britain, as is here in the US. It's amazing to hear people who think the huge disparity of wealth here and over in Britain is a good thing. Good for who the country or themselves? National interest is not a concern anymore. The taxes in Britain are going after the weakest and poorest people in Britain. These tax increase will not affect the wealthy. Once again balance the budget on the backs of the poor and distressed. Here in the US they have the nerve to talk about the huge deficit yet at the same time complain about not letting the Bush TAX cuts expire? Can someone explain to me who has a problem with our debt, and complains about government spending explain how every economist says letting the tax cuts to the wealthy expire is the most effective ways to deal with our defecit? Lower taxes for the rich, does nothing for the economy, they just send the money in overseas bank accounts that arent taxed. They are looting America, like they did in Russia and Argentina. We are next. They will wipe out the middle class in this country. ...that is their goal now. More for them, less and less for everyone else...yet more money in the hands of lower paying workers does. This is fact, and you cant argue with it. It doesnt stimulate the economy to give more to the wealthy, Clinton's administration did the opposite of what Republicans say, and it was good for the economy. Ultimately that is the key these people dont care about America. These people dont believe in our nation anymore, they have written it off, and are trying to suck as much out of it for themselves. This is disgraceful, and it is un-American.
He could start by eliminating most of the useless, parasitic bureaucrats that infest the public payroll.
So in other words, they are trying to turn the UK into the US.  God help them.

Let's acknowledge that the residents of modern Beijing should have the benefit of decent plumbing, heating and so forth- no one should have to live in depressed conditions for the benefit of foreign tourists.  Even so, the solution proposed (and, in so many cases, already implemented) by the Chinese government is no real solution at all.  Transforming living-history into kitschy attractions for those same benighted tourists (complete with costumed folk dancers and dragon-shaped 'coasters, no doubt) will end up making a bad situation even worse.  The Chinese have already turned much of the Great Wall into a theme park, with tee-shirt salesmen cozying up to tourists at every reconstructed guard tower. The few remaining hutongs have similarly been turned into tourist showpieces with special lunches offered to special (paying) "friends."  If antiquated residential buildings cannot be repaired and modernized (at least internally), they should probably be knocked down. But, for heavens sake, preserve what CAN be preserved of history without turning it into a Formica exhibition.  If they can manage this in India and in Egypt, a far wealthier Chinese government should be able to accomplish the same.

We can't really judge Cameron after only a few weeks, but we can be encouraged by the conservative steps he has taken to reign in the excesses within the economy. I applaud his actions, as well as the people of England for realizing times are not good today, and will only get worse if corrective actions aren't taken. At least the English people are try to do something. Yes, many will face harder times, more sacrafices, etc. but the country will be better off. I am becoming scared where the Obama administration is taking this country; not just him but Senators and Congressman are not providing the leadership. Seems they can only come up with more costly programs, more bailouts, less taxes, and larger debts. This pace will result in the U.S. becoming a second, or third rated country.
If you have eight million long-term unemployed people, trying to save tens of billions of dollars by adding to the unemployed list does not seem to make much sense to me. Then again....

There is so much land there, yet the destroy history..

On the other hand, NA does the same but with younger buildings.

The problem is people don't really see the consequences of past mistakes or we wouldn't be in this mess.
I am all for different countries trying different approaches and seeing what works, but if Britains approach fails will the republicans admit they were wrong? If it succeeds will the democrats admit they were wrong?
My prediction is it will do some good for Britain in the long run (10+ years) but hurt the country terribly in the short to medium time frames, and my further prediction is the republicans will claim the REASON it failed is because of the higher taxes on the wealthy in Britain.

In Tucson the handful of Territorial era adobe homes that escaped destruction in the 1960s and 1970s (City of Tucson torn down over 30 blocks of old houses and businesses for a convention center and police headquarters) are now worth huge amounts of money. Too bad China hasn't realized that tourists would rather see authentic buildings than modern replicas.
It is simply absurd to think more spending with huge deficits is smart strategy. No economist can convince me that up is down - yet they try -straight faced. Cameron is doing the right thing. Bravo.

We might not have the advantage of learning from two different experiments on two sides of the Atlantic. The sizes / populations / military engagement and spending / business ethos and neighborhood relationships are different. This calls for different strokes for different folks.
I can imagine unemployed Brits subsisting on boiled potato and Shakespeare.Can you imagine an American easily giving up 'pork' especially if all that is required is a swipe of the plastic?
A Brit would go to Africa / Asia or to the farthest corner of the world in search of employment / adventure. Au contraire, an American might hardly know where these places are.
Both the governments are only trying to preserve the kind of life their citizens are already used to. Both might succeed.Let Obama complete his plan implementation.

There have been a number of comments on this article that have surprised me. True, perhaps the hutongs don't have modern amenities that many associate with modern living. However, I echo the sentiment of one reader that these courtyards are full of history and lifelong memories. I grew up in a hutong with my grandparents, aunt and uncle, and cousin. Though I often reluctantly shared our outhouse with spiders (and other bugs) and the kitchen was black with coal at times, there were many things in that hutong not found in modern high-rises, like the easy feeling of summer as we sat on our porches eating watermelon with our neighbors. I can still see our living room, the place of countless grandchildren's birthdays, family reunions, big dumpling dinners for Chinese New Year. I remember my grandma's "little dark room", so named because it occupied the place indoors directly behind our outdoor kitchen, which blocked the sun. It was where she and I took naps every afternoon while listening to Chinese comedians on the radio. There are memories in these places, and while it may seem that I'm waxing poetic, these images are what come to my mind when I think of hutongs. Bulldozing them for the malling of China seems like such a tactless, disrespectful gesture to those who lived there. How can money ever buy back memories? Perhaps the government should focus their attention on renovating these places to improve the quality of life for the residents, but keep the inherent spirit of the place alive.

You have to admire the strategy though.  The elite seize the economic reins, screw everything up, the common people bail them out depleting the treasuries, and then they close the doors on the common people by gutting education, healthcare, transportation and any other means to rise in the ranks.  No competition with the elite and their children. The Lords and Nobility's last hurrah to maintain power and deny any real equality and powering sharing.  It could be called the era of Tudor-redux!

Andy, in case you need a reason not to listen to Steve McIntyre, here is an example of what a nasty, petty little man he is:

http://climateaudit.org...

Don't talk to him, it is the best tribute you can give to Schneider

(the link in the last one was wrong, where's the preview button?)
Oh please! Why pick on Newark. As if you couldn't say the same about NYC, LA, Miami, or even! still! Cleveland for that matter.

The NHL has rejected the deal, stating that it circumvents the salary cap rules. Good! It's a blatant attempt to cheat the system. It's about time the league stopped these types of long term contracts.
